safety: ⚡ Use anti-static wrist strap when handling components
🔥 Handle lithium batteries with extreme care - no metal tools near battery
🌬️ Work in well-ventilated area when using isopropyl alcohol
🧤 Wear safety glasses when prying components
tools: 📷 Smartphone or camera to document disassembly steps
🧩 Organizer tray for screws and small components

Camera problems may include blurry photos, focus issues, black screen, or rattling sounds. Which camera is affected?

🔧 Initial Preparation

 ⚠️ Please first power off the device before proceeding with the disassembly.
📱 Remove the SIM card tray and external accessories connected to the device.
🧤 Use anti-static precautions when handling internal components. 

What components would you like to extract first?

🔋 Battery

⚠️ WARNING 
Batteries are made out of lithium-ion, which can be dangerous if punctured or damaged. It is advised to let professionals handle this type of battery. 

Do you still want to proceed?

steps.action: If there is a metal shield over the battery connector, remove it using a precision screwdriver.
Disconnect the battery connector using a non-metallic pry tool. This should always be your first step to prevent short circuits!

nodes.text: Are there any pull-tabs or adhesive strips on the battery?

steps.action: Slowly and firmly pull the adhesive strips at a shallow angle (less than 45°), keeping them parallel to the phone's base.
Once loosened, gently lift the battery. Avoid bending it more than 30 degrees to prevent damage.

If it's hard to pull, apply 90% (or higher) concentration isopropyl alcohol near the battery edges. Let it sit for 1-2 minutes to soften the adhesive. Use a plastic tool to gently pry off the battery.
Apply 90% (or higher) concentration isopropyl alcohol near the battery edges using a dropper or cotton swab.
Let it sit for 3-5 minutes to fully soften the adhesive - patience is key here!
Use a plastic pry tool then gently lift the battery from the housing. Work from multiple sides gradually.

nodes.text:
Once the battery is dismantled:
Store the batteries safely in a fireproof container
🚫 Do not bend, puncture, or expose the battery to high temperatures
♻️ Consider professional recycling options for lithium batteries
Which camera do you want to extract?

steps.action: Locate the rear-facing camera (usually at the top right, protected by a metal bracket).
If there are any mounting brackets securing the module, note the screw sizes before removing them.
Disconnect the flex cables near the rear-camera module carefully using a plastic spudger - these are fragile!
Gently lift the rear-camera module straight up to avoid damaging the lens assembly.
Remove or lift the display (if not already done). Carefully open the screen using a plastic spudger and suction cup. Be mindful of flex cables attached near the top of the display.
Locate the front camera module at the top edge of the screen assembly, embedded in a black flex cable cluster.
Remove any brackets or shields using a precision screwdriver - keep screws organized!
Disconnect the front camera flex cable using a plastic pry tool. Apply gentle pressure only.
Gently lift the camera module using plastic tweezers or a spudger. If glued, apply a drop of isopropyl alcohol (90%+) and wait 30-60 seconds before lifting.

nodes.text:
Camera Removal Complete!
Avoid touching the camera lens to prevent smudges or scratches
Store the cameras in a dust-free container
Consider using lens covers for protection during storage

steps.action: Use a plastic spudger to disconnect all visible flex cables linked to the charging port assembly. Take photos before disconnecting for reassembly reference.
Use a precision screwdriver to remove all fasteners securing the charging port or its flex cable. Organize screws by size and location.
If the flex cable is glued to the frame, apply 90% or higher isopropyl alcohol along the edges. Wait 1-2 minutes to allow the adhesive to soften.
Use a plastic card or tweezers to gently lift and peel away the entire charging port flex cable. Work slowly - these components are extremely fragile!
Disconnect all visible flex cables connected to the logic board using a plastic spudger. Number each connection or take photos for reference.
Remove metal shields or brackets covering connectors or chips with a precision screwdriver. Note shield locations as some are thermal pads.
Unscrew the logic board from the device frame (usually 2-5 screws). Keep track of screw lengths and positions.
Check for hidden connections. Shine a light to spot any missed flex cables or antennas before lifting.
Gently lift the logic board starting from the bottom edge. Support it evenly to avoid bending.
Locate the speaker module at the bottom of the device, near the charging port. It's often covered by a mesh grille.
Check for overlapping components (metal brackets, antenna connectors, plastic spacer). Remove these gently using tweezers or a spudger.
Remove any screws securing the speaker. iPhone speakers typically use Phillips #000 or Tri-point screws.
Disconnect the flex cables connected to the speaker using a plastic pry tool. Apply pressure straight up, not at an angle.
Gently pry from one edge and lift the speaker module straight up to avoid damaging the diaphragm.
Locate the vibrator motor (Taptic Engine) near the lower portion of the iPhone. It's a small rectangular component.
Unscrew any mounting brackets securing the motor in place. iPhone Taptic Engines typically use 1.2mm screws.
Once unscrewed, gently lift the motor straight up. The flex cable is very short, so lift just enough to access the connector.
Disconnect the flex cable attached to the motor using a plastic pry tool. Be extremely gentle with this connection.

nodes.text:
🤖 Android Disassembly

🔧 # Initial Preparation
- ⚠️ Please first power off the device before proceeding with the disassembly.
- 📱 Remove the SIM card tray and external accessories connected to the device.
- 🧤 Use anti-static precautions when handling internal components.

🔋 Battery

⚠️ WARNING 
Batteries are made out of lithium-ion, which can be dangerous if punctured or damaged. It is advised to let professionals handle this type of battery. 

Do you still want to proceed?

steps.action: Locate the battery connector (usually found near the logic board). Many Android devices have the connector at the side rather than the top.
Disconnect the battery connector using a non-metallic pry tool. This is critical before proceeding with any repairs!

nodes.text: Are there any pull-tabs or adhesive strips on the battery?

steps.action: Slowly and firmly pull the adhesive strips at a shallow angle (less than 45°). Some Android devices have 3-4 pull tabs.
Once loosened, gently lift the battery. Many Android batteries are more flexible than iPhone batteries.
If it's hard to pull, apply 90% (or higher) concentration isopropyl alcohol near the battery edges. Let it sit for 1-2 minutes to soften the adhesive.
Apply 90% (or higher) concentration isopropyl alcohol near the battery edges. Android batteries often have stronger adhesive than iPhones.
Let it sit for 3-5 minutes to fully soften the adhesive - be patient!
Use a plastic pry tool then gently lift the battery from the housing. Work from multiple sides gradually.

nodes.text:
Once the battery is dismantled:
Store the batteries safely in a fireproof container
🚫 Do not bend, puncture, or expose the battery to high temperatures
♻️ Consider professional recycling options for lithium batteries
Which camera do you want to extract?

steps.action: Locate the rear-facing camera (usually at the top of the device). Many Android phones have multiple camera modules.
If there are any mounting brackets securing the module, unscrew them. Note that different cameras may have different bracket sizes.
Disconnect the flex cables near the rear-camera module carefully. Some high-end Androids have ribbon cables instead of flex cables.
Gently lift the rear-camera module. Be careful with periscope zoom modules as they're particularly fragile.
Remove or lift the display (if not already done). Android displays vary widely in their attachment methods (adhesive vs. screws).
Locate the front camera module at the top edge of the screen assembly. Some are under the display on newer models.
Remove any brackets or shields using a precision screwdriver. Some Androids have the front camera integrated into the display assembly.
Disconnect the front camera flex cable using a plastic pry tool. Be extra gentle with punch-hole camera modules.
Gently lift the camera module. Under-display cameras require special care - consult your specific model's guide.

nodes.text:
Camera Removal Complete!
-Avoid touching the camera lens to prevent smudges or scratches
-Store the cameras in a dust-free container
-Consider using lens covers for protection during storage

steps.action: Use a plastic spudger to disconnect all visible flex cables linked to the charging port assembly. Android ports often have more connections than iPhones.
Use a precision screwdriver to remove all fasteners securing the charging port or its flex cable. Some models have the port soldered to the board.
If the flex cable is glued to the frame, apply 90% or higher isopropyl alcohol along the edges. Wait 1-2 minutes to allow the adhesive to soften.
Use a plastic card or tweezers to gently lift and peel away the entire charging port flex cable. Many Androids combine the charging port with the speaker assembly.
Disconnect all visible flex cables connected to the logic board using a plastic spudger. Android boards typically have more connections than iPhones.
Remove metal shields or brackets covering connectors or chips with a precision screwdriver. Some shields are soldered on.
Unscrew the logic board from the device frame (usually 2-5 screws). Some models have the board in multiple pieces.
Check for hidden connections. Android boards often have coaxial antenna cables that are easy to miss.
Gently lift the logic board. Some models require removing daughter boards first.
Locate the speaker module at the bottom of the device, near the charging port. Some Androids have dual speakers.
Check for overlapping components (metal brackets, antenna connectors, plastic spacer). Speaker assemblies vary widely across brands.
Remove any screws securing the speaker. Some models use Torx screws instead of Phillips.
Disconnect the flex cables connected to the speaker using a plastic pry tool. Some high-end models have waterproof seals around the speaker.
Gently pry from one edge and lift the speaker module straight up. Avoid damaging the speaker mesh.
Locate the vibration motor near the lower portion of the phone. Android vibrators are often round (unlike iPhone's rectangular Taptic Engine).
Unscrew any mounting brackets securing the motor in place. Some are simply glued in place.
Once unscrewed, gently lift the motor straight up. The vibration motor is often connected by two thin wires rather than a flex cable.
Disconnect the wires attached to the motor using plastic tweezers. These connections are often very fragile.

nodes.text:
✅ Processing complete. Remember to:
1. 📦 Store components properly in anti-static bags
2. ♻️ Recycle through certified e-waste channels
3. 🗑️ Wipe any personal data using factory reset or specialized tools
4. 🧰 Organize your screws and components for future use

Thank you for recycling responsibly! 🌍
